intro: Quercus ceripes, commonly known as the red oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its deeply lobed leaves that turn reddish in the fall. The tree produces acorns, which are an important food source for various wildlife species. Its bark is rough and fissured, providing habitat for small animals and insects. Quercus ceripes typically grows to a height of 20–40 meters and is well adapted to a variety of soil types.
